Peyton Farquhar.sentence: II Peyton Farquhar was a well to do planter, of an old and highly respected Alabama family.
III As Peyton Farquhar fell straight downward through the bridge he lost consciousness and was as one already dead.
Peyton Farquhar was dead; his body, with a broken neck, swung gently from side to side beneath the timbers of the Owl Creek bridge.

Della.sentence: Now, when the income was shrunk to 20, though, they were thinking seriously of contracting to a modest and unassuming D. But whenever Mr. James Dillingham Young came home and reached his flat above he was called Jim and greatly hugged by Mrs. James Dillingham Young, already introduced to you as Della.
Della finished her cry and attended to her cheeks with the powder rag.
Della, being slender, had mastered the art.
Had the queen of Sheba lived in the flat across the airshaft, Della would have let her hair hang out the window some day to dry just to depreciate Her Majestys jewels and gifts.
One flight up Della ran, and collected herself, panting.
Give it to me quick, said Della.
When Della reached home her intoxication gave way a little to prudence and reason.
Della doubled the fob chain in her hand and sat on the corner of the table near the door that he always entered.
His eyes were fixed upon Della, and there was an expression in them that she could not read, and it terrified her.
Della wriggled off the table and went for him.
Cut it off and sold it, said Della.
You neednt look for it, said Della.
For there lay The Combsthe set of combs, side and back, that Della had worshipped long in a Broadway window.
And then Della leaped up like a little singed cat and cried, Oh, oh!

James Dillingham Young.sentence: Also appertaining thereunto was a card bearing the name Mr. James Dillingham Young.

Now, when the income was shrunk to 20, though, they were thinking seriously of contracting to a modest and unassuming D. But whenever Mr. James Dillingham Young came home and reached his flat above he was called Jim and greatly hugged by Mrs. James Dillingham Young, already introduced to you as Della.

Jim.sentence: Now, when the income was shrunk to 20, though, they were thinking seriously of contracting to a modest and unassuming D. But whenever Mr. James Dillingham Young came home and reached his flat above he was called Jim and greatly hugged by Mrs. James Dillingham Young, already introduced to you as Della.
Tomorrow would be Christmas Day, and she had only 1.87 with which to buy Jim a present.
Only 1.87 to buy a present for Jim.
Something fine and rare and sterlingsomething just a little bit near to being worthy of the honor of being owned by Jim.
Had King Solomon been the janitor, with all his treasures piled up in the basement, Jim would have pulled out his watch every time he passed, just to see him pluck at his beard from envy.
It surely had been made for Jim and no one else.
With that chain on his watch Jim might be properly anxious about the time in any company.
If Jim doesnt kill me, she said to herself, before he takes a second look at me, hell say I look like a Coney Island chorus girl.
Jim was never late.
The door opened and Jim stepped in and closed it.
Jim stopped inside the door, as immovable as a setter at the scent of quail.
Jim, darling, she cried, dont look at me that way.
Jim, and lets be happy.
asked Jim, laboriously, as if he had not arrived at that patent fact yet even after the hardest mental labor.
Jim looked about the room curiously.
Shall I put the chops on, Jim?
Out of his trance Jim seemed quickly to wake.
Jim drew a package from his overcoat pocket and threw it upon the table.
But she hugged them to her bosom, and at length she was able to look up with dim eyes and a smile and say: My hair grows so fast, Jim!
Jim had not yet seen his beautiful present.
Isnt it a dandy, Jim?
Instead of obeying, Jim tumbled down on the couch and put his hands under the back of his head and smiled.

Sofronie.sentence: Madame, large, too white, chilly, hardly looked the Sofronie.

The Old Man.sentence: Whenever it fell upon me, my blood ran cold; and so by degreesvery graduallyI made up my mind to take the life of the old man, and thus rid myself of the eye forever.
I was never kinder to the old man than during the whole week before I killed him.
And this I did for seven long nightsevery night just at midnightbut I found the eye always closed; and so it was impossible to do the work; for it was not the old man who vexed me, but his Evil Eye.
I had my head in, and was about to open the lantern, when my thumb slipped upon the tin fastening, and the old man sprang up in bed, crying outWhos there?
I knew what the old man felt, and pitied him, although I chuckled at heart.
The old man, I mentioned, was absent in the country.

The Officers.sentence: There entered three men, who introduced themselves, with perfect suavity, as officers of the police.

A shriek had been heard by a neighbour during the night; suspicion of foul play had been aroused; information had been lodged at the police office, and they the officers had been deputed to search the premises.
I gasped for breathand yet the officers heard it not.

John.sentence: It is very seldom that mere ordinary people like John and myself secure ancestral halls for the summer.
John laughs at me, of course, but one expects that in marriage.
John is practical in the extreme.
John is a physician, and perhapsI would not say it to a living soul, of course, but this is dead paper and a great relief to my mindperhaps that is one reason I do not get well faster.

I sometimes fancy that in my condition if I had less opposition and more society and stimulusbut John says the very worst thing I can do is to think about my condition, and I confess it always makes me feel bad.
I even said so to John one moonlight evening, but he said what I felt was a draught, and shut the window.
I get unreasonably angry with John sometimes.
But John says if I feel so I shall neglect proper self-control; so I take pains to control myself,before him, at least,and that makes me very tired.
but John would not hear of it.
There comes John, and I must put this away,he hates to have me write a word.
John is away all day, and even some nights when his cases are serious.
John does not know how much I really suffer.
I meant to be such a help to John, such a real rest and comfort, and here I am a comparative burden already!
I suppose John never was nervous in his life.
I always fancy I see people walking in these numerous paths and arbors, but John has cautioned me not to give way to fancy in the least.

When I get really well John says we will ask Cousin Henry and Julia down for a long visit; but he says he would as soon put fire-works in my pillow-case as to let me have those stimulating people about now.
John thought it might do me good to see a little company, so we just had mother and Nellie and the children down for a week.
John says if I dont pick up faster he shall send me to Weir Mitchell in the fall.
I had a friend who was in his hands once, and she says he is just like John and my brother, only more so!
Of course I dont when John is here, or anybody else, but when I am alone.
John is kept in town very often by serious cases, and Jennie is good and lets me alone when I want her to.
And I know John would think it absurd.
John says I mustnt lose my strength, and has me take cod-liver oil and lots of tonics and things, to say nothing of ale and wine and rare meat.
And dear John gathered me up in his arms, and just carried me upstairs and laid me on the bed, and sat by me and read to me till it tired my head.
I never thought of it before, but it is lucky that John kept me here after all.
I wonderI begin to thinkI wish John would take me away from here!
It is so hard to talk with John about my case, because he is so wise, and because he loves me so.
John was asleep and I hated to waken him, so I kept still and watched the moonlight on that undulating wallpaper till I felt creepy.
I got up softly and went to feel and see if the paper did move, and when I came back John was awake.
John says it is good for me, and to sleep all I can.
The fact is, I am getting a little afraid of John.
I have watched John when he did not know I was looking, and come into the room suddenly on the most innocent excuses, and Ive caught him several times looking at the paper!
John is so pleased to see me improve!
I cant do it at night, for I know John would suspect something at once.
And John is so queer now, that I dont want to irritate him.
There are only two more days to get this paper off, and I believe John is beginning to notice.
John knows I dont sleep very well at night, for all Im so quiet!
It only interests me, but I feel sure John and Jennie are secretly affected by it.
John is to stay in town over night, and wont be out until this evening.
I dont want to go out, and I dont want to have anybody come in, till John comes.
Why, theres John at the door!

Mary.sentence: It is fortunate Mary is so good with the baby.

Henry.sentence: When I get really well John says we will ask Cousin Henry and Julia down for a long visit; but he says he would as soon put fire-works in my pillow-case as to let me have those stimulating people about now.
I tried to have a real earnest reasonable talk with him the other day, and tell him how I wish he would let me go and make a visit to Cousin Henry and Julia.

Julia.sentence: When I get really well John says we will ask Cousin Henry and Julia down for a long visit; but he says he would as soon put fire-works in my pillow-case as to let me have those stimulating people about now.
I tried to have a real earnest reasonable talk with him the other day, and tell him how I wish he would let me go and make a visit to Cousin Henry and Julia.

Nellie.sentence: John thought it might do me good to see a little company, so we just had mother and Nellie and the children down for a week.

Jennie.sentence: John is kept in town very often by serious cases, and Jennie is good and lets me alone when I want her to.
It is only three weeks more and then we will take a nice little trip of a few days while Jennie is getting the house ready.
He seems very queer sometimes, and even Jennie has an inexplicable look.
I caught Jennie with her hand on it once.
And I heard him ask Jennie a lot of professional questions about me.
It only interests me, but I feel sure John and Jennie are secretly affected by it.
Jennie wanted to sleep with methe sly thing!
Jennie looked at the wall in amazement, but I told her merrily that I did it out of pure spite at the vicious thing.
Ive got a rope up here that even Jennie did not find.
I wont, even if Jennie asks me to.

Weir Mitchell.sentence: John says if I dont pick up faster he shall send me to Weir Mitchell in the fall.

Jane.sentence: Ive got out at last, said I, in spite of you and Jane!
